bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, April 29, [1900?]

div1.p: Carter describes his life in Cuba. He discusses the Cuban-American political situation.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Eugenia Hook Carter, April 29, [1900?]
div1.p:
I have had a pretty de-
cent week -- not well all the time
but not sick. No Fell Feeling good for no-
thing rather than anything else. I do not
know whether to come down from my
tower or stay where I am. It is very
comfortable & above all, very quilt quiet. who
gevenwhen I get here; but no special pleas-
ure to come. It is 99 steps from the
ground floor -- which is 2 steps from
the side street.

I get summer rates from May 1st so
you can feel less compunctions
about money. I pay $15.00/100 per month
less. I paid $37 00/100 for a new uni
form & one extra pair of trousers-wih
I could have gotten as good for $25
& it grievously hurts my feelings. Am
2
having a couple of Khaki suits made
at $7 00/100 each, which is cheap. They
will also be cool & not require so much
washing.

It is so long aft before I return that I find
it best not to think of it. Only two months
have gone -- & I have surely done two mos.
of work. At last I can see the way out
of my tangle -- the station is straightening
out pretty fairly. I have two good
men - Frick & McConnell -- acting assis-
tants -- the other two Dudley & Scheneshew-
sky (Regular officers) are not satisfactory
still the work is done. It will be all of
May however before I can say how it will
be done during the summer. This I will -- say that as worrying
as much of it has been. I have been interes-
ted in it. There has been no lack of perso-
nal interest, & I have felt its full im-
C1

portance.

The Cuban election will affect the Cuban
sanitary requirements of the Cuban muni-
cipalities & some extent affect my
work between the different Cuban cities.
I think, it will lighten it. I have my work so
arranged that, we can drop the Cuban from
the U. S. part of it without any organic
hitch -- the two divisions have no organic
union. I don't much care how soon the sep-
aration comes, the sooner the better.

Your last letter said the spring had be-
gun -- rather a late spring, but people in
the tropics have no idea of the beauty
C1
B29
of the spring & of the fall in the our country
infinitely more beautiful than in Cuba
Please God. We will see next spring to-
gether.

Give my dear love to Mother & to
all at N. River & Ashland & Do not be wor-
ried at any reasonable amount of lan-
guor in anyone during May & June. It
isn't sickness & the remedy is (1) small doses
of Q & Strychnic & (2) take up some regular
definite work. It is not so hard to go out
all day as it is to saunter about, & 3 go out
doors.
